Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2013 08:20AM SwoosieQue wrote: I'm not sure if my experience will help you because my situation is different, but I had implants put in back in 1979, I never had them removed or replaced, just this year when I was diagnosed with Invasive, Well-differentiated ductal carcinoma, I chose bilateral mastectomy.   I'm nearly at 7 or 8 weeks post-op and my surgeon gave me the report of everything that happened during my surgery, there was a notation that the implant on my right breast (the one that had cancer and the core biopsy) had "leaked", silicone gel had spread through the calcification area... I did not know this at the time of my last visit with the surgeon, otherwise, I would have asked her if this implant burst during surgery or was burst prior to surgery, like maybe during the core biopsy. I know that it is NOT typical for implants to last 35 years, but mine did!  My left one was intact when they removed my left breast. Don't know if this helps, hope it does.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with LCIS with Breast Implants TLA SwoosieQue

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2013 06:04AM SwoosieQue wrote: Foreverchanged, I am learning that TE problems are much more common than I had ever anticipated.  I wasn't expecting this, especially since so many family members have gone through reconstruction without any hitches!   At my PS appt. yesterday, I tried to be 'sneaky' and asked her if she would be returning the TE for the manufacturer to inspect and whether or not someone, other than me, would be responsible for the 20% copay I now have to pay for the hospital, anesthesiologist, doctor fees and whatever else is involved.  The hospital already phoned me yesterday, telling me how much I have to pay when I check in.   Oops, got off the track there.  Anyway, the doctor told me that there could have been a problem with the TE moving, even flipping on itself, like a dog ear - 2 layers, which then could have caused her to puncture it when doing a fill.  She said that she would talk with her Accounting person to see if they could forego her fees.  We'll see.
Posts.Title: Defective Tissue Expander SwoosieQue SwoosieQue

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2013 02:58PM SwoosieQue wrote: Thank you Blessings!
Posts.Title: Defective Tissue Expander SwoosieQue SwoosieQue

Posts.Content: SwoosieQue wrote: I hope that I'm posting this in the correct area, I couldn't find an area specific to reconstruction.  My apologies if this is in the wrong place. I'm 7 weeks post-op, simple, bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction.  My fills include 100cc at time of surgery, 100cc 3 weeks post-op, 2 weeks later another 200cc and the next fill-up was scheduled for yesterday, but, the doctor just filled up the left one with 200cc because it looked like it was leaking.  Her exact words, "It looks empty." I had phoned the day after my last fill, concerned because I could tell that the left one was leaking but the doctor was in surgery, so I asked to speak with the nurse who was unavailable but would phone me later.  When she phoned, she told me that it's typical for tissue expanders to look uneven, she wasn't grasping that this was not a matter of uneven, it was a matter of deflation! I'm so upset right now, I don't know if I'm making any sense, I can't think straight.  I'm scheduled for a replacement surgery 2 days from today.  I'm upset about having to go through another major surgery only 7 weeks post-op when I'm finally starting to feel better and see a light at the end of the tunnel.  I'm upset because when I asked the plastic surgeon's office manager, "Who is going to pay for this?", she bluntly said that the insurance company would.  Yeah, but I have to pay my 20% copay since my deductible has already been met and who's going to reimburse me??? My husband is livid, he is so angry, he's talking about suing the manufacturer. Can anyone here help me, your experience, your feelings, your 'happy ending'?  Please.  I think I need to go cry now. BRCA1 & 2 negative, Oncotype DX: 1, just turned 60yrs. old. "We are at our very best when things are at their worst." Dx 6/19/2013, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Surgery 8/13/2013 Mastectomy: Left, Right; Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Hormonal Therapy 9/10/2013 Arimidex (anastrozole) Surgery 10/3/2013 Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Defective Tissue Expander SwoosieQue SwoosieQue

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2014 04:50PM SwoosieQue wrote: Just jumping in to say 'congratulations' on your successful MRI.  I found this thread fascinating as everyone talked about their oncologists.   When I was first diagnosed, I felt lost, wondering how on earth to find my "team".  I was fortunate when the wife of a friend of my husband talked with me and gave me the names of her "team".  Talbert was my breast surgeon; the plastic surgeon whom I wanted (and worked very closely with Talbert) was no longer working with Mercy hospital, so, Talbert contacted another plastic surgeon to do the "immediate reconstruction".  I am not happy with that plastic surgeon and am in the process of switching to my first choice, now that I don't have to be limited to Mercy for my exchange surgery. Dr. Talbert was my breast surgeon and Dr. Theobald is my oncologist - both were contracted with Integris, Talbert (at that time) was contracted with Mercy, where I had my surgery. I think you are in good hands if you follow farmerlucy and okiemomof4's advice for doctors. Good luck from a fellow Okie!
